description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server 2012 is designed to be a mid-tier certification for someone who has been working in the field for several years and has had exposure to large and enterprise size deployments of Microsoft Windows and covers topics that are a “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows Server 2012 servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA 70-411 Administering Windows Server 2012 exam covers administering Windows services, keeping them operational, advanced functionality and other areas that will help in your pursuit of the MCSA and also help in an after pursuit of the MCSE certification.
name: MCSA Windows Server 2012 - 70-411
subtitle: Administering Windows Server 2012

episodes.description: MCSA Windows Server 2012 (70-411) Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server 2012 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows Server 2012 servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA covers topics that will help the learner ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Overview of Windows Server 2012 R2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.758
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.758 --> 00:00:12.563
The MCSA or Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate is one of

3
00:00:12.563 --> 00:00:16.210
the more popular
certifications from Microsoft.

4
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:19.160
It's designed to be
a mid-tier certification.

5
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:23.530
Greater knowledge than somebody who's
just getting started in IT, but

6
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:25.450
not expert lever, level knowledge.

7
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:28.330
This is somebody who's been working
in the field for several years and

8
00:00:28.330 --> 00:00:33.700
has had exposure to large and enterprise
size deployments of Microsoft Windows.

9
00:00:33.700 --> 00:00:37.860
The MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 is probably the most

10
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:40.900
commonly sought-after
certification with Microsoft.

11
00:00:40.900 --> 00:00:44.190
These are for technicians who are not
going to be just working with desktops,

12
00:00:44.190 --> 00:00:46.450
but deploying Windows servers.

13
00:00:46.450 --> 00:00:50.130
These might be email servers,
file servers, print servers.

14
00:00:50.130 --> 00:00:52.040
They might be authentication servers.

15
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:55.210
There's all sorts of different types
of servers you might deploy, and

16
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:58.640
the MCSA for Windows Server 2012
covers the majority of them.

17
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:01.780
It shows typical deployment scenarios for
a server.

18
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:05.290
How to deploy the software successfully,
how to secure the software and

19
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:09.000
ensure things are working nice and
smooth, and how to troubleshoot and

20
00:01:09.000 --> 00:01:11.680
isolate and correct issues when they
aren't running nice and smooth,

21
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:14.080
and that makes this really valuable.

22
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:18.570
If you're working in IT and you're sitting
at a help desk right now, or you're doing

23
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:22.060
field repairs on computers and you're
looking to move to that next step in your

24
00:01:22.060 --> 00:01:26.560
career, the MCSA for Windows Server
2012 is normally that next step, right.

25
00:01:26.560 --> 00:01:30.090
This is what gets you out of the field and
back at the data center.

26
00:01:30.090 --> 00:01:32.470
Gets you into the server room,
working in equipment there.

27
00:01:32.470 --> 00:01:35.360
Which is usually a little more
exciting than supporting a desktop.

28
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:37.850
Which can,
can over time become a bit monotonous.

29
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:39.360
I think we've all been there.

30
00:01:39.360 --> 00:01:41.210
So, let's take a look at
this certification and

31
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:42.720
get a better idea of what it entails.

32
00:01:42.720 --> 00:01:46.226
All right, the MCSA has been around for
quite a while now.

33
00:01:46.226 --> 00:01:49.227
I don't think it's actually
reached ten years yet but it's,

34
00:01:49.227 --> 00:01:51.090
it's a good seven years at least.

35
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:54.410
And it's designed to be the,
well that mid-tier certification.

36
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:56.500
The name has changed a little
bit over the years, but

37
00:01:56.500 --> 00:01:59.560
now it's just the Microsoft
Certified Solutions Associate.

38
00:01:59.560 --> 00:02:02.500
And Microsoft actually has
several different ones.

39
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:05.570
The one we're about to cover is
the one for Windows Server 2012.

40
00:02:05.570 --> 00:02:10.130
If your position within the company is
one that allows you to work on servers,

41
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:11.900
that's what this is designed for.

42
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:15.940
If you're still at the desktop level but
you want to move into the server world,

43
00:02:15.940 --> 00:02:18.390
again, this is the place
that you wanna go.

44
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:21.600
But, if you're looking to
do desktop support, well,

45
00:02:21.600 --> 00:02:23.840
the server technologies,
they can be helpful.

46
00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:26.230
They help you to understand what's
going on on the server side.

47
00:02:26.230 --> 00:02:28.440
But it's not necessarily
the right place for you to start.

48
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:32.840
You typically want to go to the MCSA for
Windows 8 or MCSA for Windows 7.

49
00:02:32.840 --> 00:02:35.250
Now, if you're just
getting started in IT so

50
00:02:35.250 --> 00:02:40.250
you've got a resume full of other jobs and
you're looking to launch an IT career.

51
00:02:40.250 --> 00:02:44.460
Well again the MCSA for Windows servers
is not really a great starting point.

52
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:46.120
In order to set up a server,

53
00:02:46.120 --> 00:02:49.590
there's a lot of foundational
knowledge that you need to have.

54
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.750
So if you're just starting out,
I recommend you jump over to

55
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:56.440
like the CompTIA A+ and
CompTIA Network Plus certifications.

56
00:02:56.440 --> 00:02:59.940
Those are great starting points for
launching an IT career.

57
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:02.470
If you're just getting started
in technology altogether you

58
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:07.440
probably wanna go to either
the CompTIA IT Fundamentals or the MTA,

59
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:09.570
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

60
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:13.410
That's designed for people that are just
getting their feet wet in the IT world.

61
00:03:13.410 --> 00:03:15.270
You'll learn about basic
operating systems.

62
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:18.740
Now, that's foundational knowledge
that you're expected to already

63
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:21.050
have by the time you get
to the server level.

64
00:03:21.050 --> 00:03:22.400
So if you don't possess it,

65
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:25.360
there's things that we'll cover in there
that might be a little over your head.

66
00:03:25.360 --> 00:03:26.940
That if you've missed
the foundational knowledge,

67
00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:28.600
you won't be able to build on top of it.

68
00:03:28.600 --> 00:03:31.120
So, definitely check out those
other certifications if you

69
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:32.560
haven't done those yet.

70
00:03:32.560 --> 00:03:33.770
But, if you're ready for

71
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:37.650
Windows Server, then the MCSA
2012 is where you want to go.

72
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:42.620
Now, the MCSA 2012 is actually
built on three different exams,

73
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:46.080
and each one kind of divides
the topic up a little bit.

74
00:03:46.080 --> 00:03:48.350
So, here we can see the three
different exams, and

75
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:51.410
we divide it here on ITPROTV
into three separate shows.

76
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:53.840
There's the 70-410, 411 and 412 shows.

77
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.940
The first one is installing and
configuring Windows Server 2012.

78
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:01.010
If this is the first time you've used it,

79
00:04:01.010 --> 00:04:03.140
we'll cover how to install
Windows Server 2012.

80
00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:06.920
How to get it in place, and
how to add roles to it so

81
00:04:06.920 --> 00:04:09.670
your server can actually
perform customized functions.

82
00:04:09.670 --> 00:04:11.540
We'll talk about
the Microsoft Active Directory,

83
00:04:11.540 --> 00:04:14.970
which is a critical technology
throughout your server infrastructure.

84
00:04:14.970 --> 00:04:18.840
We'll talk about other security concepts,
and just some of the neat bells and

85
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:23.020
whistles that are included
in Windows server.

86
00:04:23.020 --> 00:04:25.680
Then, in 411, we go into
Administering Windows Server 2012.

87
00:04:25.680 --> 00:04:30.440
Once you've brought up these services,
now you need to administer them,

88
00:04:30.440 --> 00:04:31.280
you need to run them.

89
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:35.100
You need to allow it to scale up
to thousands, tens of thousands,

90
00:04:35.100 --> 00:04:36.680
hundreds of thousands of users.

91
00:04:36.680 --> 00:04:41.000
You need to keep it operational and you
need to do some advanced functionality.

92
00:04:41.000 --> 00:04:44.540
And what, that's what we cover in the
Administering Windows Server 2012 show.

93
00:04:45.780 --> 00:04:48.830
And then the end of it is the 70-412

94
00:04:48.830 --> 00:04:52.930
which is Configuring Advanced
Windows Server 2012 Services.

95
00:04:52.930 --> 00:04:56.890
We actually revisit some of the services
from the first two shows, and

96
00:04:56.890 --> 00:05:00.310
go more in depth,
showing some advanced configurations, and

97
00:05:00.310 --> 00:05:04.550
then we phase in some new technologies
like Active Directory Federated Services

98
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:08.040
that are extremely complex and
challenging.

99
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:10.780
Not useful at all for
small and medium businesses.

100
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:13.990
But for large and
enterprise businesses can revolutionize

101
00:05:13.990 --> 00:05:15.630
the way that you offer
services on the web.

102
00:05:15.630 --> 00:05:19.740
So, definitely stuff that you want
to be aware of, and get exposed to.

103
00:05:19.740 --> 00:05:25.580
Now these exams are designed to be taken
in order, so you should start with 70 410.

104
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:28.420
And then go on to 411 and
then wrap it up with 412.

105
00:05:28.420 --> 00:05:31.170
If you take them out of order,

106
00:05:31.170 --> 00:05:35.270
each exam assumes you already have
the knowledge from the prior exams.

107
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:37.490
So for example if you start out on 412,

108
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:40.680
it assumes you already
have a passing knowledge.

109
00:05:40.680 --> 00:05:43.720
Like you passed the exam,
not just in passing.

110
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:46.540
Of 410 and 411.
If you don't do that, you'll,

111
00:05:46.540 --> 00:05:49.340
you'll get over your head pretty quick and
then you get frustrated and

112
00:05:49.340 --> 00:05:51.470
it's hard to be successful
when you're frustrated.

113
00:05:51.470 --> 00:05:54.470
So you do wanna pursue those in order.

114
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:59.220
Now for me, I always recommend that
people go ahead and do all three.

115
00:05:59.220 --> 00:06:01.310
Just watch all three in order.

116
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:04.030
Even before taking that 410 exam.

117
00:06:04.030 --> 00:06:08.890
And the reason I say that is, each one
builds on the one from before it so

118
00:06:08.890 --> 00:06:10.200
there's some overlap.

119
00:06:10.200 --> 00:06:13.560
And that means you're seeing the same
technologies multiple times and

120
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:15.030
you learn more about it.

121
00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:18.860
If you were to watch all three of
these shows, 410, 411, and 412,

122
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:23.690
you'll be much more likely to pass that
410 exam the first time you go in there

123
00:06:23.690 --> 00:06:25.990
cuz you've seen the technology so
many times.

124
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:26.620
All right?

125
00:06:26.620 --> 00:06:29.120
So how you choose to watch
them is ultimately up to you,

126
00:06:29.120 --> 00:06:32.360
but at a minimum,
you do want to watch them in order.

127
00:06:32.360 --> 00:06:35.550
Start with 410, and
then move through each.

128
00:06:35.550 --> 00:06:38.800
When you're ready to take the exam,
the exams are administered through

129
00:06:38.800 --> 00:06:42.540
Pearson VUE, so
you'll just jump over to their website.

130
00:06:42.540 --> 00:06:45.930
You can go straight to it at
www.pearsonvue.com/Microsoft.

131
00:06:45.930 --> 00:06:48.770
That'll take you to Microsoft's page.

132
00:06:48.770 --> 00:06:53.957
And remember VUE is spelled V U E and
so it's pearsonvue.com/microsoft.

133
00:06:53.957 --> 00:06:59.200
The exams are $150 a piece and
you gotta take three of them so

134
00:06:59.200 --> 00:07:02.510
unfortunately there is a little bit
of a shock to the wallet on this one.

135
00:07:02.510 --> 00:07:07.500
Assuming you pass on the first time it'll
be about $450 to take the three exams.

136
00:07:07.500 --> 00:07:11.420
Once you pass,
you get your MCSA Window's Server 2012.

137
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:17.830
Now the MCSA Windows Server 2012 is also
the first step in obtaining the MCSE.

138
00:07:17.830 --> 00:07:21.120
So once you've completed this
certification the next step is that

139
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:22.840
MCSE that you hear a lot
of people talk about.

140
00:07:22.840 --> 00:07:26.310
Right, that's the, the certification
Microsoft has that's the most famous.

141
00:07:26.310 --> 00:07:28.720
Everybody's heard of the MCSE.

142
00:07:28.720 --> 00:07:30.500
And that's a lot of people's goal.

143
00:07:30.500 --> 00:07:34.490
But, the MCSE is not designed for
somebody getting started.

144
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:38.140
It's for somebody who's already
got a wealth of experience.

145
00:07:38.140 --> 00:07:40.430
Already has their MCSA, and

146
00:07:40.430 --> 00:07:45.450
is moving into that larger
consultant type design environment.

147
00:07:45.450 --> 00:07:49.380
And that's a lot different than the person
who's doing the day to day work.

148
00:07:49.380 --> 00:07:51.710
The MCSA is for the doer.

149
00:07:51.710 --> 00:07:52.810
The person who's in the field.

150
00:07:52.810 --> 00:07:54.600
The grunt who's actually
making things happen.

151
00:07:54.600 --> 00:07:56.750
Right?
You're the one bringing up servers and

152
00:07:56.750 --> 00:07:57.310
troubleshooting.

153
00:07:57.310 --> 00:07:58.160
Replacing hard drives.

154
00:07:58.160 --> 00:08:00.260
You're the one who's
actually making things work.

155
00:08:00.260 --> 00:08:04.220
So in a lot of ways, the knowledge we
cover in the MCSA certification is more

156
00:08:04.220 --> 00:08:09.140
valuable than what we learn in the MCSE
and the MCSA is a lot more entertaining in

157
00:08:09.140 --> 00:08:12.770
my opinion because you know, you get
to use a lot of these technologies.

158
00:08:12.770 --> 00:08:14.280
So keep that in mind as you go through and

159
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:18.570
study that the MCSA is a great place to
start if you're already somebody who has

160
00:08:18.570 --> 00:08:22.110
that experience and you're looking to get
that documented, get it on your resume and

161
00:08:22.110 --> 00:08:26.200
learn all the different things
that Windows Server 2012 can do.

162
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:29.070
All right, well, if that's what you're
looking for, you're in the right place.

163
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:31.200
Stay tuned, our episodes are coming up.

164
00:08:31.200 --> 00:08:34.510
If not, keep in mind all the other
certifications that I mentioned.

165
00:08:34.510 --> 00:08:36.590
There's an appropriate one for
you in there somewhere.

166
00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:39.720
You just gotta look to find it and
then pursue your goal.

167
00:08:39.720 --> 00:08:42.890
Regardless of which route you go,
I wish you the best of luck on your exam.

168
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:44.320
And for those of you sticking with me,

169
00:08:44.320 --> 00:08:46.272
I'll see you in the episodes
here in just a moment.

170
00:08:46.272 --> 00:08:53.079
[SOUND]

topics.title: Overview of MCSA Windows Server 2012 R2 (70-411)

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Mike take a look at Windows Deployment Services. They demonstrate installing the WDS role and configuring install and boot images. They also take a look at discover and capture images as well as demonstrate capturing a syspreped reference machine.
episodes.title: Deploy and Manage WDS

episodes.description:
After or about the 40 minute mark. A command was missing to enable the feature: `DISM /Image:c:\mount /Enable-Feature /FeatureName:TelnetClient`  
This should be run before you check it with: `DISM /Image:c:\mount /Get-Feature /FeatureName:TelnetClient`

In this episode Mike and Nate wrap up WDS by demonstrating image maintenance procedures such as adding system updates and building driver packages. They also show how to add features to an offline image.
episodes.title: Windows Deployment Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel explain some of the features and functionality of Microsoft's patch management system, Windows Server Update Service(WSUS). Here specifically, they talk all about installing and configuring the WSUS role. They show you how to add the role and then configure the service based on best practices so that only updates you need are getting downloaded and installed to your clients. They also talk about the different modes (Autonomous/Replica) for implementing multiple WSUS servers.
episodes.title: Configuring WSUS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on configuring patch management using WSUS from Microsoft. This time they move on to configuring group policy for the purposes of configuring automatic updates on the client systems and other update settings. Other topics discussed include client-side targeting, WSUS synchronization, WSUS groups, and patch management in a mixed environment.
episodes.title: Configuring WSUS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don discuss remotely managing Windows servers. They demonstrate how to aggregate event logs as well as utilize other monitoring tools for troubleshooting and monitoring purposes.
episodes.title: Monitoring Servers

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to upload driver packages into Windows Deployment Services (WDS). He also shows how to use groups and filters to restrict what drivers apply to what hardware.
episodes.title: Driver Groups and Packages

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates using Windows Server Update Services (WSUS) to manage updates in an environment where multiple operating systems are in use.
episodes.title: Patch Management in Mixed Environments

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore the Performance Monitor system built into the Windows Server 2012R2 operating system. They show you how to configure Data Collector Sets as well as Alerts. They also show you how to perform real-time monitoring of performance, as well as monitoring virtual machines and system events. Also covered is network monitoring and scheduling performance monitoring.
episodes.title: Performance Monitor

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don demonstrate how to install and configure Distributed File System (DFS). They highlight some of the advanced functionality as well as show how DFS can improve redundancy and reliability for corporate file servers.
episodes.title: Distributed File System

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel begin to explain and configure the File Server Resource Manager(FSRM) in Windows Server 2012R2. They start by overviewing the FSRM role and then move into one of the features that FSRM provides, which is quota management. This allows you to set disk quotas, giving you a system for making sure that disk space is being protected from over utilization.
episodes.title: File Server Resource Manager

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel finish their overview of the File Server Resource Manager, this time covering File Screen Management and Storage Reports. First they take a look at the File Screen Management system witch allows you to specify what types of files are allowed or disallowed. Finally they show you how to configure the Storage Reports to generate reports based off of your specified criteria.
episodes.title: File Server Resource Manager Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Don describes file encryption types in Windows Server 2012 and management concerns in an enterprise environment. He also demonstrates how to configure BitLocker on a Windows Server and shows off the new BitLocker Network Unlock feature.
episodes.title: File and Disk Encryption

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don discuss backing up a certificate private key and setting up a data recovery agent in a domain environment. They explore audit policies and several different methods for configuring them such as local policy, AuditPol.exe and domain-based group policy.
episodes.title: EFS and Audit Policies

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Daniel take a look at DNS zones inside a Microsoft Active Directory Domain. They start by explaining how to configure the traditional Primary and Secondary zones and how they work. Then they cover the advantages of using an Active Directory Integrated zone and the security features found therein. Also covered are DNS Stub zones.
episodes.title: Configure DNS Zones

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain how to configure the different resource records in DNS on a Windows Server 2012 server. They begin by explaining the common DNS resource records like A and AAAA records, as well as CNAME, PTR, and SOA. Other topics discussed SRV records, zone scavenging, and setting the record Time-to-Live for the client cache.
episodes.title: Configure DNS Records

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Don take a look at installing and configuring the Remote Access role in Windows Server 2012 R2. They demonstrate how to implement basic routing, Network Address Translation (NAT) and how to allow and deny remote users from connecting to the VPN.
episodes.title: Configure VPN and Routing

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Mike take a look at the roles and components required for implementing DirectAccess and demonstrate its use. They also demonstrate configuring DNS and certificates as well as testing the settings by connecting a remote client machine.
episodes.title: Configuring DirectAccess

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don discuss two methods for preventing undesired machines from accessing your network. They start at looking at Network Policy Server (NPS) and describe how it can be used to filter incoming dial-up and VPN connections. Then they go on to extend NPS by adding Network Access Protection (NAP) to further secure the network by ensuring clients meet a predetermined list of requirements.
episodes.title: NPS and NAP

topics.title: Configure a Network Policy Server infrastructure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike describe the Operation Master Roles available to a Windows Server 2012R2 server in an Active Directory Domain. These roles include Schema Master, Domain Naming Master, Relative Identifier(RID) Master, Primary Domain Controller(PDC) Emulator and Infrastructure Master. They cover each Operation Master role and describe the when, where, and why you would employ each in your domain.
episodes.title: Operation Master Roles

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel show you how to install and configure a Read-Only Domain Controller(RDOC) in a Microsoft Active Directory Domain. RDOCs help address come of the challenges that an enterprise infrastructure can encounter at the branch office and/or perimeter networks that might not be as physically secure as a main datacenter.
episodes.title: Read Only Domain Controllers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike go over configuring account policies in Active Directory Users and Computers. They kick things off by demonstrating how to configure both domain and local user password policy settings. This includes things like minimum/maximum password age, history, and complexity requirements. They then move into delegating password management and configuring lockout policies. Finally they look into kerberos policy settings.
episodes.title: Configure Account Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel describe the Group Policy Processing order and precedences which will help you figure out how to properly configure and deploy your group policies. They also explain and configure inheritance blocking and policy enforcement.
episodes.title: Group Policy Processing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue describing Group Policy Processing and this time they are looking at configuring security filtering and Windows Management Instrumentation(WMI) filtering. First they cover security filtering, which is a way of refining which users and computers will receive and apply the settings in a GPO. Then they go over WMI filtering which allows you to dynamically determine the scope of GPOs based on attributes of the target PC.
episodes.title: Group Policy Processing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel finish exploring Group Policy Processing, covering a myriad of topics such as configuring loopback processing, configuring and managing slow-link processing and Group Policy caching, configuring client-side extension(CSE) behavior, and forcing Group Policy updates.
episodes.title: Group Policy Processing Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel begin explaining how to configure Group Policy in Windows Server 2012R2. Here they start by showing you how to access the Group Policy Management Editor and from there they show you how to configure Group Policy Object(GPO) settings. This includes settings that affect software installation, folder redirection, scripts, and administrative template settings.
episodes.title: Group Policy Settings

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Daniel continue configuring Group Policy Object settings in Windows Server 2012R2. Here they pick up by showing you how to create and import security templates as well as custom administrative template files. They also show you how to configure property filters for administrative templates.
episodes.title: Group Policy Settings Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore management and best practices concerning Group Policy Objects. They explain the importance of and show you how to perform administrative tasks like backing up, importing, copying, and restoring GPOs. They then show you how to create and configure a Migration table and resetting default GPOs. Finally they cover delegating management of Group Policy to share the administrative load with other trusted users.
episodes.title: Group Policy Objects

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explain and configure Group Policy Preferences. They start by explaining what the difference between Group Policy Objects, Group Policies, and Group Policy Preferences are. Then they move into how you can use Group Policy Preferences to configure settings for printers, network drives, power options, Internet Explorer, and others. They also cover item-level targeting to change the scope of individual preference items.
episodes.title: Group Policy Preferences
